# Edge Runtime

The Next.js Edge Runtime is based on standard Web APIs, which is used byMiddlewareandEdge API Routes.

# Network APIs

  • addEventListeneropen in new window- Fetchopen in new window- FetchEventopen in new window- Headersopen in new window- Requestopen in new window- Responseopen in new window- URLSearchParamsopen in new window- FormDataopen in new window- Fileopen in new window- Blobopen in new window

# Encoding APIs

  • TextDecoderopen in new window- TextEncoderopen in new window- atobopen in new window- btoaopen in new window

# Web Stream APIs

  • ReadableStreamopen in new window- ReadableStreamBYOBReaderopen in new window- ReadableStreamDefaultReaderopen in new window- TransformStreamopen in new window- WritableStreamopen in new window- WritableStreamDefaultWriteropen in new window

# Web Crypto APIs

  • cryptoopen in new window- CryptoKeyopen in new window- SubtleCryptoopen in new window

# Web Standards APIs

  • structuredCloneopen in new window- URLPatternopen in new window- Web Cacheopen in new window

# V8 Primitives

  • Arrayopen in new window- ArrayBufferopen in new window- Atomicsopen in new window- BigIntopen in new window- BigInt64Arrayopen in new window- BigUint64Arrayopen in new window- Booleanopen in new window- clearIntervalopen in new window- clearTimeoutopen in new window- consoleopen in new window- DataViewopen in new window- Dateopen in new window- decodeURIopen in new window- decodeURIComponentopen in new window- encodeURIopen in new window- encodeURIComponentopen in new window- Erroropen in new window- EvalErroropen in new window- Float32Arrayopen in new window- Float64Arrayopen in new window- Functionopen in new window- Infinityopen in new window- Int8Arrayopen in new window- Int16Arrayopen in new window- Int32Arrayopen in new window- Intlopen in new window- isFiniteopen in new window- isNaNopen in new window- JSONopen in new window- Mapopen in new window- Mathopen in new window- Numberopen in new window- Objectopen in new window- parseFloatopen in new window- parseIntopen in new window- Promiseopen in new window- Proxyopen in new window- RangeErroropen in new window- ReferenceErroropen in new window- Reflectopen in new window- RegExpopen in new window- Setopen in new window- setIntervalopen in new window- setTimeoutopen in new window- SharedArrayBufferopen in new window- Stringopen in new window- Symbolopen in new window- SyntaxErroropen in new window- TextDecoderopen in new window- TextEncoderopen in new window- TypeErroropen in new window- Uint8Arrayopen in new window- Uint8ClampedArrayopen in new window- Uint16Arrayopen in new window- Uint32Arrayopen in new window- URIErroropen in new window- URLopen in new window- URLSearchParamsopen in new window- WeakMapopen in new window- WeakSetopen in new window- WebAssemblyopen in new window

# Environment Variables

You can useprocess.envto accessEnvironment Variablesfor bothnext devandnext build.

Runningconsole.logonprocess.envwill notshow all your Environment Variables. You have to access the variables directly as shown below:

console.log(process.env)
// { NEXT_RUNTIME: 'edge' }
console.log(process.env.TEST_VARIABLE)
// value

# Unsupported APIs

The Edge Runtime has some restrictions including:

  • Native Node.js APIsare not supported. For example, you can't read or write to the filesystem- node_modulescanbe used, as long as they implement ES Modules and do not use native Node.js APIs- Callingrequiredirectly isnot allowed. Use ES Modules instead

The following JavaScript language features are disabled, andwill not work:

  • eval: Evaluates JavaScript code represented as a string- new Function(evalString): Creates a new function with the code provided as an argument- WebAssembly.compile- WebAssembly.instantiatewitha buffer parameteropen in new window

In rare cases, your code could contain (or import) some dynamic code evaluation statements whichcan not be reached at runtimeand which can not be removed by treeshaking. You can relax the check to allow specific files with your Middleware or Edge API Route exported configuration:

export const config = {
  runtime: 'experimental-edge', // for Edge API Routes only
  unstable_allowDynamic: [
    '/lib/utilities.js', // allows a single file
    '/node_modules/function-bind/**', // use a glob to allow anything in the function-bind 3rd party module
  ],
}

unstable_allowDynamicis aglobopen in new window, or an array of globs, ignoring dynamic code evaluation for specific files. The globs are relative to your application root folder.

Be warned that if these statements are executed on the Edge,they will throw and cause a runtime error.
